text: I'm Seamus Mullen from El cu√±ado
butchery and today we're going to be
butchering one of my favorite animals
the lamb I grew up on a small farm in
Vermont we raised our own lamb we
butcher down lamb we made our own lamb
sausage cooking with whole animals has
been a part of my life since I was a kid
most people are familiar with leg of
lamb or lamb chops but they're all these
great off cuts of lamb that actually
have more flavor than the principal cuts
so this is about a 55 pound lamb I'm
going to just jump in and start taking
apart whatever you're butchering the
most important thing is to look for
joints within the bone I'm going to
start by taking the neck out the neck is
a great cut for braising the next
section here this is sort of the rib
section and now we're going to get into
the chops and the ribs
okay so now we have the ribs on one side
and is the breasts on the other side so
you can either cook the whole thing
together you can cure it overnight and
that's great as Ewing barbecue if you
want to smoke something you've probably
heard of Denver ribs that's what people
talk about when they talk about lamb
ribs or you can take the ribs off and
then cook the breast on its own I love
it it's very fatty and if you want to do
something really cool you can take the
breast all the way down pretty much to
the end like that just season it up with
a little pepper mix like that some salt
whatever you have lying around terms of
herbs in the rosemary obviously goes
really well with lamb a little bit of
lemon zest and add some okay garlic in
there like that roll it up like that
pick some string we're going to cook it
low and slow so all that stuff's just
going to come apart season it up on the
outside I think now you're seeing a lot
of different cuts on restaurant menus
that have a tremendous amount of flavor
and it's very inexpensive for recipes
using some of my favorite cuts of lamb
go to Bon Appetit comm slash lamb
